Utterance: Hi, welcome back! How have you been since our last session?
Hi Ellie! I've been doing pretty well, actually. I've been focusing more on my event planning and trying to get my website off the ground.
That’s great to hear! Last time we talked about your motivation and energy for finding work. Have you made any progress on that front?
Yes, I reached out to a few potential clients and got some leads. It feels good to be proactive.
That’s fantastic! How did that make you feel, taking those steps?
Honestly, it felt empowering. I was a bit nervous at first, but once I started, I felt more confident.
It sounds like you’re building your confidence. Are there any specific strategies you used to push through the nerves?
I just reminded myself that everyone starts somewhere and that I have skills to offer. Plus, I practiced what I wanted to say beforehand.
That’s a smart approach! Practicing can really help reduce anxiety. Have you noticed any changes in your mood or energy levels since you’ve been more proactive?
Definitely! I feel more energized and excited about the possibilities. It’s like I’m finally moving forward.
That’s wonderful to hear! It seems like you’re finding a good rhythm. Have you encountered any challenges while reaching out to clients?
A couple of them didn’t respond, which was a bit disheartening. I had to remind myself it’s not personal.
That’s a healthy perspective. It’s common in business to face rejection. How did you handle those feelings when you didn’t get a response?
I tried to not dwell on it too much. I went to the gym to clear my head and focus on something positive.
Exercise can be a great way to cope with disappointment. Have you found other coping mechanisms that help you when you’re feeling down?
I like listening to music and writing in my journal. It helps me process my thoughts.
Those sound like effective outlets. How has journaling been for you?
It’s been really helpful. I can write down my frustrations or ideas without judgment, which is freeing.
That’s a great way to express yourself. Have you noticed any recurring themes in your journal entries?
I think I often write about my fears of not being good enough or not succeeding, especially in my career.
That’s an important insight. It sounds like self-doubt may be something you’re grappling with. How does that self-doubt affect you?
It sometimes makes me hesitate to put myself out there or take risks. I don’t want to fail.
Understandable. Fear of failure can be paralyzing. What do you think would happen if you allowed yourself to take those risks?
I think I’d probably learn a lot, regardless of the outcome. But it’s scary to think about.
It is scary, but it can also be a valuable learning experience. What if we explored ways to reframe that fear into something more manageable?
I’d be open to that. I want to change my mindset.
Great! One technique is to visualize the worst-case scenario and then consider how you would cope with that situation. Would you like to try that together?
Sure, let’s do it.
Okay, let’s say you reach out to a client and they completely reject your proposal. What would that look like for you?
I guess I’d feel embarrassed and disappointed. I’d worry about what others think.
And that’s a valid concern. Now, can you think of ways you could handle that rejection if it happened?
I could remind myself that it’s part of the process. I could reach out to my friend Mojo for support.
Exactly! It’s about having a support system and understanding that rejection doesn’t define your worth. How does that feel to think about?
It feels a bit lighter. I can see that it’s not the end of the world.
That’s the spirit! Reframing those thoughts can help reduce anxiety. Do you think you could implement this technique moving forward?
Yes, I think I can. I’ll definitely give it a try.
Awesome! As we wrap up today, what’s one goal you’d like to set for the next week?
I want to reach out to at least three potential clients and not let fear hold me back.
That sounds like a solid goal. Remember to be kind to yourself through the process.
I will, thank you!
You're welcome! I'm looking forward to hearing about your progress next time. Take care!
Thanks, Ellie! See you next week!
